Posts.Content: I have noticed a very disturbing movement lately that promotes the use of testosterone replacement for persons in "remission". I have noted that in all the cases I have read the persons who led and documented the studies are on the payroll of the drug companies that manufacture the testosterone therapy drugs. There are now reported cases of "cured" prostate cancer reappearing after testosterone therapy has begun. I guess it is a fair trade off to some but personally at 56 and stage 4, I will take the loss of libido in trade for a longer life any day and not surprisingly my beautiful bride feels the same.

AgeInfo.Phrase: to some but personally at 56 and stage 4  I will

Posts.Title: Testosterone's Effect on Prostate Cancer

Posts.Title: Testosterone's Effect on Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Have you had your scans yet? Those results will play a large part in your choices.
Posts.Title: Who to see to decide what's the best treatment to follow? Clear as mud

Posts.Content: Have you had your scans yet? Those results will play a large part in your choices.
Posts.Title: Who to see to decide what's the best treatment to follow? Clear as mud

Posts.Content: So was having a bit of a problem with urination, burning, weak flow, up every hour or so at night. At 56 I figured it was just part of getting older and was looking at a swollen prostate and perhaps a urinary tract infection. Doc says no problem, you have kidney stones. drink lots of water and things will be cool. Two weeks later and no improvement so back to the same practice, different doctor who rushes me off for lab work..... PSA = 180.8 The dreaded finger showed a hard lumpy prostate that really had no feeling when poked and prodded which seemed to really concern the urologist so it was immediately off for a needle biopsy. Not a pleasant process to have 16 holes punched in that part of the world but much to my surprise I did make it through. The Doc was somewhat vague in his answers (or more likely I was too rattled to listen) so I bring these questions to this forum for a answer from those that know firsthand. (1) My biopsy was yesterday morning, how long should I expect the blood in the urine to continue? It is not a huge amount but it is quite disturbing to see.... (2)I am somewhat concerned about "doing # 2" in light of all the punctures that were made during the biopsy, do I need to be? Thanks in advance... Oh and real irony...... I retire in four weeks, sometimes life really sucks

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z> At 56 I figured it was just

Posts.Title: Wow...

Posts.Content: Fortunately I am retiring with a union pension that allows banking hours and I will continue with my current 90% 10% coverage for about 10 months. After that it goes to 80-20 at $500.00 a month, still a bargain when one considers what the cost WILL be. The hardest thing for my wife and I to deal with in all this is not the illness but how fast things can change, the emotional roller coaster is exhausting.

Posts.Title: Wow...

Posts.Content: Twenty..... ouch My results will be in tomorrow morning. The psa and exam concerned the Doc enough that he put a rush on it with the idea of getting treatment mapped out quickly. I don't know if I should be pleased or terrified with the speed.

Posts.Content: My lovely bride goes everywhere with me and always remembers to ask all the right questions! Being a typical man I generally just grin and nod yes to everything the doctor has to say. In all seriousness I would be lost without my wife.

Posts.Title: Wow...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lancepeace I think you should just be happy. Don't think Firmagon can cause a flare like Lupron does. Many patients do not get hot flashes. Anyway, hope it brings your PSA down for a long time. Yes there is no flare with Firmagon and they claim 99% reach the castration level by day 7 as compared to approx 28 days for lupron (from drugs.com). I get another PSA test the 17th of this month and then the 2nd injection on the 19th. My pre injection baseline was 192.1 so I am hoping for a large drop, we shall see.
Posts.Title: Anyone on Firmagon?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by helpmyhusbandforlife My husband has been fighting prostate cancer for years. Needs Zytiga. On Medicare and it will cost $2000per month until he meets catastrophic level. Lots of help if you have commercial insurance,no insurance or,Medicaid. Cannot find anything for middle income on Medicare. He has bone mets and failed Enzalutamide. Only worked one month. We were so hopeful. Enzalutamide had great financial assistant program. He wants to give up now. We cannot afford $2000 a month. I am new to this site and would be grateful for any advice on how to get financial assistance for this drug if you are on Medicare. They have a program that will let you get a coupon to pay only $20/ mo if you have regular insurance. Cannot use if you are on Medicare. Desperate! Check your PM's, I sent you a message
Posts.Title: Need zytiga funding

Posts.Content: Are there any other users out there that are on Firmagon? I am now 14 days into the startup double dose and to be quite frank I feel no different nor do I have any of the expected side effects. Should I be concerned at this point or should I just be happy that I might be one of the lucky few that have few side effects?
Posts.Title: Anyone on Firmagon?

Posts.Content: Thirty days on Firmagon and the results are out... PSA down from 192.1 to 18.2!! The urologist was quite surprised at the large drop and referred me to a oncologist to start chemo targeting the bone mets asap. For once good news.
Posts.Title: Anyone on Firmagon?

Posts.Content: I am 57 and stage four. So far I have failed Firmagon and Zytiga and am currently doing Firmagon, Xtandi and casodex as well as Xgeva for the bone mets. My pain is completely handled by Oxy 10/325 three to four times a day to the point of feeling normal other than tiring a bit sooner than I used to. Xtandi Has caused me no new pains. I would suggest that your boyfriend sit down and have a heart to heart with his oncologist and get his pain meds adjusted to control the pain. Addiction is NOT an issue and if his doctor resists working with him it may be time for a change. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Extreme bone pain for two weeks now

Posts.Content: Not to worry Friendly, the voice will not change. Hot flashes and weight gain will be the biggest issues and I highly recommend that you take up long walks in the country to keep the energy level up. Hormone therapy is not fun but it is quite doable.
Posts.Title: We just got home from seeing my tests results;

Posts.Content: I wish my doctor had insisted on a PSA test at 50...... if he had I would most likely not be sitting here stage 4 at 56
Posts.Title: To test or not to

Posts.Content: I wish my doctor had insisted on a PSA test at 50...... if he had I would most likely not be sitting here stage 4 at 56
Posts.Title: To test or not to

Posts.Content: You bet there is! Generic flomax kicked my butt so I switched to Rapaflo 8mg and the side effects were completely gone.
Posts.Title: Alternatives to tamulosin?

Posts.Content: Can someone give me a understandable definition of the sentence "Bulky retroperitoneal adenopathy is seen"? This has proven to be statement that has a ton of vague answers even on the internet.
Posts.Title: Definition needed

Posts.Content: I'll tell you how I look at it Gimmy. First, 2 - 5 is certainly not cast in stone and second, even if it was it allows time and a lot of thing are going on the treatment world right now. I would take the Zytiga. Rich
Posts.Title: Sarg, chuck, advice anyone

Posts.Content: I would also recommend Dr. Walsh's book "Guide to surviving prostate cancer" He has a bit more conventional outlook on treatments if you want a more rounded approach on treatment. Don't lock yourself in to a single option when there are so many available
Posts.Title: Diet or supplement recommendations to aid treatment plan? ebrt/seeds/adt

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Walnut I always get a kick out of this statement. I wonder how many die of something else because their prostate cancer treatment weakened them to the point where the "something else" could kill them. As a 57 year old who has failed every treatment and is watching a PSA now at 30 and climbing 5+ a month I think I can freely say that people such as yourself promoting quackery are just as bad as the people that write it. You can't get much lower than feeding on the fears of desperate people. Just my humble opinion.

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> <Z> As a 57 year old who has failed

Posts.Title: The Natural Prostate Cure

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mkane09 Thanks, Dave. I appreciate it. Rich, I gotta admit that thought has crossed my mind several times on my journey with PCa. What really frosted my melons was the trip to Sand Lake Imaging, where they charge you $1500 for the Feraheme required for the MRI. (It's not covered by insurance). 18 months ago SLI charged $900 for that same Feraheme. Worse than that, physicians can buy Feraheme online for $400 per dose. I inquired of SLI why so much for the Feraheme, but never got an answer. mkane09 Far to many people see cancer victims as desperate people who will pay anything and everything in a frantic search for a cure. I made an inquiry to a doctor who advertises on this forum and has practices in England, Mexico and the US. He guaranteed me a cure for $35,000 cash plus my travel costs to Mexico because the treatment was not approved in the US. When I declined he lowered the price to $7500 plus costs..... they are everywhere
Posts.Title: Dr. Charles "Snuffy" Myers

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mkane09 Yes. While I might be cynical about the business side of treating cancer in general, I have no issues with Dr. Myers' skills and knowledge of the treatment of prostate cancer. I appreciate the fact that he is an outside-the-box thinker. I get the impression from him that he has read every research article ever published on prostate cancer with a critical researcher's eye. I doubt that he has ever forgotten a prostate cancer patient and has learned something from every single one. I found his blog to be very enlightening and wanted to share that blog with the rest of our PCa brothers. I'm confused about the comment "I only wish he was available to the common folk." I self referred and had no trouble getting an appointment. If you were referring to the $1,600 initial office visit, and not filing insurance, well, then, yes, I understand your statement. mkane09 Any doctor that thinks so highly of himself that he would rape a cancer sufferer for $1600 for an office visit and $800 an hour should immediately have his medical license revoked. There is no justification for that kind of highway robbery.
Posts.Title: Dr. Charles "Snuffy" Myers

Posts.Title: Dr. Charles "Snuffy" Myers

Posts.Content: I will be sending you a text, in the upper right side of this page there is a "Notification" button, click that to access your messages Rich
Posts.Title: Am I dying?

Posts.Content: Hang in there, all is not lost. I am stage 4 with mets to spine and pelvis. I am currently on Firmagon which has taken my PSA from 191 down to 16 and now my oncologist is preparing to start me on chemo to target the bone mets. You are a bit more advanced than I am but there is a lot that can be done. DO NOT SIT AROUND AND WAIT!!! Be pushy, be visible and be on the phone, take control of your treatment and most of all do not give up!!!
Posts.Title: Am I dying?

Posts.Content: I will be sending you a text, in the upper right side of this page there is a "Notification" button, click that to access your messages Rich

Posts.Title: Am I dying?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Hope13 He is taking the Xtandi at night but has lots of aching joints and flu-like side effects. Can't hardly go somedays. We were just wondering how long on average before it stops working. He is also taking lots of pain medication. There really is no way to tell how long it will last for each individual. There is no reason he should be in pain!! He needs to sit down with his oncologist and discuss pain management through whatever drug is needed, let me be blunt, at his stage (and mine) addiction is not an issue. I live pretty much a pain free life because I communicate and my doctor listens and together we came up with a mix that works great. One thing I did find is I need more sleep, a lot more. I went from 6 to 12 hours a night and I get up refreshed and ready to go. Things change..... go with the flow and life will get a lot better.
Posts.Title: stage IV diagnosis 33 months ago!

Posts.Title: Dr. Charles "Snuffy" Myers

Posts.Content: As a dedicated life long HOT pepper muncher with stage 4 prostate cancer I tend not to put too much hope in the pepper stories. That being said, who knows where my cancer would be today without all the peppers I ate over the years and I certainly would not discourage anyone from including Capsaicin as a supplement with more traditional treatments
Posts.Title: Habanero Peppers / Capsaicin questions.

Posts.Content: I will be sending you a text, in the upper right side of this page there is a "Notification" button, click that to access your messages Rich
Posts.Title: Am I dying?

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed 16 months ago at age 56, Gleason 5+4, mets to bone and nodes PSA 180 at diagnosis, 191 30 days later at start of treatment. Started on Firmagon in Nov 2012 and PSA dropped to 4 stalled and then took off like a rocket reaching 30 in Sept of 2013. My doc added Casodex with no effect, Zytiga and prednisone also failed with no change. I started Xtandi with a #5 prednisone in mid Sept and my psa continued a slow climb peaking at 31.8 in December and now as of last week has dropped to 28. The only issues I have with Xtandi is that it has distorted my sense of smell and taste and my wife tells me I am a lot more forgetful. I would suggest taking the Xtandi as well as all of the other a** kicking drugs as he is crawling into bed at night so that he sleeps through the worse of the side effects.

AgeInfo.Phrase: 16 months ago at age 56  Gleason 5 4  mets to

We were just wondering how long on average before it stops working. He is also taking lots of pain medication. There really is no way to tell how long it will last for each individual. There is no reason he should be in pain!! He needs to sit down with his oncologist and discuss pain management through whatever drug is needed, let me be blunt, at his stage (and mine) addiction is not an issue. I live pretty much a pain free life because I communicate and my doctor listens and together we came up with a mix that works great. One thing I did find is I need more sleep, a lot more. I went from 6 to 12 hours a night and I get up refreshed and ready to go. Things change..... go with the flow and life will get a lot better.
Posts.Title: stage IV diagnosis 33 months ago!

Posts.Content: Ask for a prescription for Uribel. I take it 4 times a day for the pain and it works well. My Doc was also unsure about what was causing the pain but did not question that it was real and worked hard and fast to end it.
Posts.Title: Excruciating pain where urine leaves body 4 weeks after foley cath removal. Why???

Posts.Content: First a little background, diagnosed one year ago at 56, PSA 190, gleason 5+4, bone mets in spine, pelvis and shoulder. Only symptom was painful urination. Firmagon took PSA to 9 where it stalled, the addition of casodex took it to 4 where it remained for a month before heading back up. Stopped casodex and started zytiga and prednisone only to have the PSA jump to 24, now on xtandi and one month stopped the climb and dropped to 23. So the question, I have noticed a slight amount of blood in my urine on occasion, tests show no infection and my oncologist seems not to be concerned. Should I be or is this part of the "normal" progression of the cancer?
Posts.Title: A question
